Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Resource Allocation with Learning in Dynamic and Partially Observable Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will research restoration of connectivity of interdependent road and service networks under uncertainty and learning. Real-life applications include post-disaster debris clearance to enable disaster response activities and interdependent infrastructure recovery and repair after a disruption. For example, when the road network is (partially) disrupted, edges (roads) need to be restored (e.g., through repair and debris clearance). The goal is to establish connectivity between supply and demand nodes in a timely manner to satisfy demand. Under uncertainty (about network conditions, and supply-demand levels), decision-making can be improved by collecting situational spatial data. However, data collection consumes time and resources. Furthermore, a common set of resources may perform both restoration and learning activities. Hence, under resource and time constraints, decisions on dynamically prioritizing edge recovery and resource allocation between recovery and learning are crucial for operational efficiency and effectiveness. This project considers the trade-off between learning and restoration activities, and decisions on (equitable and timely) resource allocation and frequency of information updates. The project will leverage the outreach network established by the Center for Health and Humanitarian Systems at Georgia Tech to disseminate results and interact with practitioners during project execution.

Previous research on network connectivity in stochastic networks with learning is limited. If successful, this project will introduce network repair models that are characterized by limited resources, uncertainty, ability to reduce uncertainty by deploying resources, and the need to maintain fairness in service access. It will contribute to a deeper understanding of how to solve dynamic multi-stage decision problems in stochastic networks that offer an opportunity to update information and in which learning and recovery actions share the same resources. This research will lead to efficient solution approaches for finding optimal or near-optimal solutions. The research team will perform structural analysis of underlying problems on simple networks, evaluate different information update mechanisms, and use those to derive insights and generate customized solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on efficient and effective restoration of connectivity of road and service networks under uncertainty and learning. The network’s edges are partially disrupted, and the goal is to establish connectivity between supply and demand nodes in a timely manner by restoring some of the disrupted edges. Each demand node has a penalty per unit time which accrues until the node is connected (via a path of restored edges) to a supply node. The problem is motivated in part by post-disaster debris clearance where roads that are (partially) closed due to debris correspond to disrupted edges in the network, debris clearance activities correspond to edge restoration. This project  differs from the majority of previous studies on network restoration due to endogeneity in restoration decisions, i.e.,the progress of restoration activities depends not only on the structure of the network but on previous decisions and actions as well.  

We first study the Endogenous Network Connectivity Restoration problem (ENCoRe), where the restoration times are known (deterministic) and the goal is to restore the edges to connect all the nodes to the a source node (origin) to minimize the total weighted connection times of the nodes. We model ENCoRe as a Mixed Integer Program (MIP) and present a portfolio of heuristics: 9 greedy heuristics and 6 tree-based heuristics which exploit the observation that the optimal solution for ENCoRe has a tree structure. In an extensive computational study on multiple types of networks, we compare the solutions generated by the heuristics, the MIP, and other algorithms from the literature. We show that the performance of our tree-based heuristics  is significantly better compared to other algorithms, generating close-to-optimal solutions. Moreover, by introducing solution improvement techniques, we are able to further improve the quality of the solutions. 


As in the case of the post-disaster debris clearance, the real-world applications of network restoration typically involve uncertainty in the restoration times or network conditions. Under uncertainty, decision-making can be improved by “learning,” e.g., by collecting situational spatial data, but that would consume time and resources. Thus, there is often a trade-off between learning and restoration activities.  


We introduce and study the Endogenous Network Restoration Problem under Uncertainty (ENRU), where the restoration times are stochastic. We analyze the structural properties of ENRU and present useful observations to inform solution approaches for this and related problems. We show that a special case of ENRU corresponds to a stochastic single machine job scheduling problem including data updates; for this special case, we develop a dynamic programming algorithm and show its competitive ratio.


To solve ENRU exactly, we propose a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) model. We also present a Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) model as a static solution method, which uses the expected restoration times as input. To use as a benchmark, we also propose a greedy heuristic. Finally, we develop a Monte Carlo Search Tree (MCST) based heuristic which utilizes the structural properties of the problem. We compare the performances of these methods in an extensive computational study. Our results suggest that a static solution approach performs significantly worse than dynamic approaches where decisions can be updated over time as information about the network is revealed. Exploiting the structure of the problem, we develop a fast and effective heuristic using a MCST framework, which utilizes spanning trees and shortest path trees in the network. It is also a flexible method, which can be adjusted to different problem sizes, and different distributions of the restoration times.

Both the deterministic and stochastic approaches can be utilized to develop work-plans for post-disaster debris clearance or other applications with endogenous restoration decisions. A work plan, i.e., a sequence of edges to restore (e.g., a sequence of roads to clear in the aftermath of a disaster), would enable better utilization of scarce resources and faster access to key facilities or affected areas.
